content: The "Port Operations Require Tough Scrutiny (PORTS) Act of 2006" may be cited as the Act. It includes provisions for the commencement of investigations. The Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to extend the time for discretionary investigations from 30 to 60 days, with a possible 10-day extension if deemed necessary. Mandatory investigations are also extended from 30 to 60 days. The Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to extend the time for discretionary investigations from 30 to 60 days, with a possible 10-day extension if necessary. The amendments apply to written notifications of proposed mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers received under section 721 of the Act on or after the enactment date of this Act. SEC. 3. ADDITIONAL MANDATORY INVESTIGATIONS. Amendments to Section 721(b) of the Defense Production Act of 1950 include changes to the President's authority in cases where an entity's actions could result in control of a person engaged in interstate commerce in the United States. Amendments to Section 721(b) of the Defense Production Act of 1950 expand the President's authority to investigate foreign mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers that could result in foreign control of critical infrastructure in the United States. Amendments to Section 721(b) of the Defense Production Act of 1950 expand the President's authority to investigate foreign mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers that could result in foreign control of critical infrastructure in the United States. The amendments include redesignating paragraphs, extending the commencement period, and defining 'critical infrastructure' as per the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The amendments to Section 721 of the Defense Production Act of 1950 broaden the President's power to review foreign mergers involving critical infrastructure in the US, including seaports. The changes apply to notifications of proposed mergers received after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. REPORT; ACTION WITH RESPECT TO CERTAIN MANDATORY INVESTIGATIONS. Amendments to the Defense Production Act of 1950 include redesignating subsections and adding a new subsection for reporting and action on mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers following investigations. The Defense Production Act of 1950 has been amended to include a new subsection for reporting and action on mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers following investigations. If the President decides not to take action, a report must be transmitted to Congress within 30 days. If a joint resolution is enacted within 45 days, the President must take necessary action to prohibit the merger, acquisition, or takeover. The Defense Production Act of 1950 has been amended to include a new subsection for reporting and action on mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers following investigations. If the merger, acquisition, or takeover has been completed, the Attorney General may seek divestment or other relief in the district courts. A joint resolution by Congress can disapprove the President's decision on the matter within 45 days. The Defense Production Act of 1950 has been amended to exclude certain days in investigations under section 721(b)(1)(A)(ii) of the Act. The amendments apply to investigations commenced on or after the enactment date of the Act. The amendments apply to investigations commenced on or after the enactment date of the Act. Annual report. The Defense Production Act of 1950 has been amended to require an annual report on presidential actions related to mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers. The report must be transmitted to the appropriate congressional committees. The Defense Production Act of 1950 now mandates an annual report on presidential actions regarding mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers, including details on corporate structures and majority shareholders involved. The report also includes a description of the decision to investigate or not investigate the merger, acquisition, or takeover. The Defense Production Act of 1950 requires an annual report on presidential actions related to mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers. The report must include details on corporate structures, majority shareholders, and the reasons for the actions. The term "appropriate congressional committees" is defined in the Act. The report must be transmitted to Congress starting in 2007 and each subsequent year. SEC. 6 of the Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to make technical changes, including adjustments to subsections (d), (e), and (h)(1). SEC. 7 focuses on verifying security measures under the C-TPAT and FAST programs. The Commissioner of the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection verifies security measures of participants in C-TPAT and FAST programs biannually. Policies are established for non-compliance, including probation or expulsion.
